prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Under freedom of information legislation, the government can be required to disclose information in its possession. This has the potential to put valuable information at risk. However, the legislation also protects certain corporate information, including trade secrets. For example, s. 17(1)(a) to (d) of the Ontario Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act[1] provides as follows:

17. (1) A head shall refuse to disclose a record that reveals a trade secret or scientific, technical, commercial, financial or labour relations information, supplied in confidence implicitly or explicitly, where the disclosure could reasonably be expected to,
prejudice significantly the competitive position or interfere significantly with the contractual or other negotiations of a person, group of persons, or organization;
result in similar information no longer being supplied to the institution where it is in the public interest that similar information continue to be so supplied;
result in undue loss or gain to any person, group, committee or financial institution or agency; or
reveal information supplied to or the report of a conciliation officer, mediator, labour relations officer or other person appointed to resolve a labour relations dispute.

Many of the decisions to date[2] have relied directly or indirectly on the definition of “trade secret” contained in the proposed Uniform Trade Secrets Act developed by the Institute of Law Research and Reform.[3] The commissioners and adjudicators have adopted a three-part test. Each part of the test must be satisfied to exempt a record from disclosure.[4] The test is as follows:
the record must reveal information that is a trade secret or scientific, technical, commercial, financial or labour relations information; and
the information must have been supplied to the institution in confidence, either implicitly or explicitly; and
the prospect of disclosure of the record must give rise to a reasonable expectation that one of the harms specified in (a), (b) or (c) of subsection 17(1) will occur.[5]
The decisions have also relied on common law principles when those principles are of assistance.[6]

Interestingly, the various freedom of information statutes offer protection beyond that available under the common law trade secret principles. Specifically, protection is extended to technical, scientific, commercial, financial and labour relations information.[7]

In summary, based on the legislative definitions and the decisions to date, businesses can be reasonably confident that confidential business information will be adequately protected under freedom of information legislation. In fact, the legislation often provides additional grounds for exemption from disclosure beyond those available at common law.[8]
R.S.O. 1990, c. F.31. See also the federal Access to Information Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. A-1.

However, with respect to access to information legislation across Canada, different definitions of trade secret, some relatively broad and others more narrow, have been used. See for example Merck Frosst Inc. v. Canada (Minister of Health and Welfare (1988), 20 F.T.R. 73, 20 C.I.P.R. 302 (T.D.) and Société Gamma Inc. v. Canada (Department of Secretary of State) (1994), 79 F.T.R. 42, 27 Admin. L.R. (2d) 102 (T.D.). Compare the decision in Ontario Access and Privacy Commissioner (Re Etobicoke Board of Education), [unreported, July 30, 1992, Order M-29], which adopted the broader definition of the Alberta Institute of Law Research and Law Reform. The British Columbia Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 165, adopts a similarly broad definition.
